Learn More About Me →

title: About Me
text:
My professional background is in wildlife ecology and management, where I have spent the past 7+ years building my career. During this time, I have worked on a variety of projects researching and managing wildlife and their habitats.



As I advanced in my wildlife career, I began to recognize that location was a linking factor for nearly all ecological data. This realization developed into a fascination in spatial ecology and geospatial technologies.

title: About Me
text:
My Interests
My professional interests are at the intersection of geospatial and ecological science, particularly projects using GIS to inform conservation efforts.

Applied Conservation Science — My work aims to inform on-the-ground management and decisions through applied research in conservation.
Spatial and Movement Ecology — I am fascinated by all aspects of wildlife space use, resource selection, and spatial ecology.
Imperiled Species Conservation — Our most imperiled species need immediate attention and sound science to support recovery and protection efforts.
Landscape Connectivity & Planning — Much of my interest in GIS relates to the use of those technologies for researching the ecological relationships of species and the landscape.
Web and Cartographic Design — My passion for web and cartographic design satisfies my artistic inclination, whether I’m delving into the intricacies of CSS code for a website or honing my skills in crafting visually appealing and effective map designs.
Open Source Programming — While I also use proprietary software, I am a big proponent of using and supporting open source projects like Posit and QGIS.

title: About Me
text:
My Highlights
In my 7+ years of progressive experience in conservation, geospatial, and environmental science, I have acquired a diverse range of expertise across multiple disciplines, which includes the following competencies.

Demonstrated experience with desktop, web, and mobile GIS software.
Working knowledge of R to perform statistical analyses, data wrangling, and data visualization.
Front-end web development experience using HTML and CSS coding languages.
Proficient in managing large datasets using standardized software and methods.
Skillful in cartographic design using open source and proprietary mapping applications.
Adept at using R Markdown and Quarto for reproducible reporting.

title: About Me
text:
Education

Formal Learning
My formal education is in wildlife conservation science and geographic information systems.

My college coursework expanded into several adjacent topics (e.g., soil science, watershed management, statistics, and forestry) which allows my work to be interdisciplinary.


Continued Learning
I pride myself on being someone who seeks out continuous learning. Be it at my work or during my free time, I love learning new techniques, workflows, and software.

Esri MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses), including Spatial Data Science and Cartography.
LinkedIn Learning, including a variety of modules on data science, coding in R, and creating maps programmatically.

title: Creating an Interactive Heatmap of GBIF Occurrences in R
text:
Please check back soon!



install.packages("rgbif")   # for accessing GBIF data
install.packages("leaflet") # for mapping data
library(rgbif)
library(leaflet)



wyoming <- name_backbone("Centrocercus urophasianus",
                          country = "US",
                          hasCoordinate = TRUE,
                          stateProvince = "Wyoming")



wyoming_coords <- wyoming$data[, c("decimalLatitude", "decimalLongitude")]



leaflet(wyoming_coords) %>% 
  addTiles() %>%
  addHeatmap(lng = ~decimalLongitude,
             lat = ~decimalLatitude,
             blur = 20,
             max = 0.1)
